reviewText:
Feels a lot like Super Hexagon.Frantic
The same controls (just rotation with 2 buttons)
The same league of difficulty (achievements are probably more difficult)
Levels are random, but consist of predefined elements
Completion based on time
Has endless modes
Simplistic, interesting graphics
Amazing soundtrackThis game, however, has a kind of a practice mode that can be enjoyed by almost everyone. It is slower and has checkpoints.
What saddens me, though, is there are only 2 sets of obstacles. There are some additional game modes that reuse those sets, and other modes that are just random, luck-based and lame.

★★★★★★★★☆☆

reviewText:
Pivvot is a fantastic strategic avoidance game in the likes of Super Hexagon or Boson-X.

It's easy to get sucked into the fantastic music and smooth gameplay, as you spin and dodge various obstacles. It also holds numerous ways of playing it, so it's balanced for all levels of expertise. It's one of those games that you'll be spending hours upong hours playing, without noticing so much time has passed.

To see more of my first impressions, see here:
Uno Looks At PIVVOT

reviewText: I wrote a review on the mobile version a while ago (http://www.80pgaming.com/content/2013/10/30/pivvot-review) and this version is even better with the addition of Looper mode, the Random Endless modes and local multiplayer. It's accessible, difficult to master and an all-around good time. I recommend getting the soundtrack too; the music is absolutely amazing.\n\nBuy a copy, get your friends to buy copies, then try to beat their scores. Good times had by all.

reviewText:
This is a great little game with a very simple premise, you rotate a little circle to avoid obstacles. It all sounds nice and straightforward and indeed the first voyage breaks you in gently with simple obstacles to build up your confidence.

DO NOT BE DECEIVED.

By the time you reach the expert voyage you will have worked out 3 things.

1) Digital input requires very precise timing.
2) The developers hate you (I can only assume a traumatic incident in a geometry class).
3) You definitely aren't coming back to beat that high score...at least not for the next half hour.

The game is a lot of fun when you hit the zone but be prepared for frustration along the way.

reviewText:
Pivvot includes awesome music with fast-sadistic gameplay.
Like in Super Hexagon etc. the point of the game is to avoid some obstacles. Sounds easy? The thing is that those obstacles get harder and the game faster and faster. Some of those are really frustrating, when you're quite bad at this xD
Tip for later: Change your sensitivity to get better at faster gamemodes.
Another good thing is that there are 8 different gamemodes and a co-op mode, so when your friends like to play non-sense, fast, dodge, reaction, colourful, music games, grab them some copies and start to play :P

I don't regret that I bought this game.
Recommended! ^^

reviewText:
If you like this kind of indie games, where you just need to do one single action, Pivvot is made for you.

Once you learn how each form works, it's a bit easier to get a good score. But still, the game will go faster and faster so you'll end up dying. It's so easy to restart that you'll restart and try to beat your score again. So addictive!! You won't quit the game until you have a good score, trust me :D

I really like the endless mode, as well as Berserk and Looper. But damn, Berserk is so damn hard.

reviewText: To call this a marginally more forgiving Super Hexagon on Rails would be a useful lie.\n\nPivvot in Voyage mode is like a forgiving but insistant teacher. The Voyage is a set of phases, alternating between a training phase (composed of 4 new obstacles) and a random phase with 4 obstacles you've seen before. If you die on a phase, you respawn at the start of the phase, like the game's saying, Ok
date: try again". This means that if you're in a training phase and don't know how to get past an obstace you're stuck until you learn how to get past it
recommended: or you get through thanks to pure dumb luck. However
hoursPlayed: each obstacle has its trick to get past it
voteText: and if you learn the tricks
helpfulPercent:
the game is simply employing that trick in time.

The upshot of this is that you will finish a Voyage at least once if you stick with it.

As for other modes
votesHelpful: they're a lot less forgiving. Endless simply throws obstacles at you until you die
votesTotal: but it throws them at you in the same order as the training phases in the voyage mode.\n\nBeserk lives up to its name
votesFunny: and is a real challenge. As is Looper.\n\nThe only downside is that there doesn't appear to be an option to quit out of a voyage. Yes
commentsCount: you can choose to return to the main menu
column16: but if you haven't finished Voyage
column17: choosing Voyage from the main menu will bring you back to the phase you're stuck on. As I'm trying to get through Expert without a death
column18: I'd really like the option to restart the Voyage from scratch. As for newbies
column19: the option would potentially be helpful as well
column20: so that they can play through parts that they're comfortable in before they return to the difficult part. As it turns out
column21: you can select the scary "Reset Voyage Progress" in the "Data Options" part of Settings
column22: but it's a non-intuitive (and scary) place to go when you just want to restart the voyage from the start. Restarting a voyage when you've not completed the existing one should not be that scary.\n\nOverall
column23: if you like twitch obstacle-dodging games
column24: it's a really nice one with a nice on-rails twist. The only thing it lacks is a less involved way to reset voyage progress. 9.5/10"

reviewText:
I've loved playing Pivvot ever since it became free on the iTunes App Store during the Christmas 2013 period, and I can definitely say it's a flawless game you should most definitely play, it's flawless on the iPod touch, iPhone and iPad, and is also flawless on a laptop or PC.

I can definitely say this is top of the class. Whitaker Trebella has truly designed one of the best flawless games around, as this is a fast-paced panic sensor game that will turn the first few minutes of gameplay into hours. I will always play this game like there is no tomorrow, as it is one of the best games around.

This game is the game you shouldn't miss, as this is the best, flawless game that will keep you going for hours on end, I absolutely recommend it all the way :-).

Alex Smithson

Pivvot ( A thrilling game of strategic avoidance ) is one of my all time favourite games to play on local multiplayer.

It gets a lot of laughs when we keep dying on the first obstacle on expert looper and it gets a lot of enraged laughs when we keep dying on the last obstacle but overall, this game is great, I suggest playing with friends (One person on keyboard, one person on mouse and two people on controllers (Xbox 360, DS4 etc if you own some), the soundtrack is great (although overpriced) and the simplicity is great (I need to stop using the word great)

reviewText:
One word - AMAZING! I just played the first part of the game, and I already feel it's worth the money, and not to mention time. Gameplay is simple (just move right and left), but cunningly difficult at the same time. There are a ton of obstacles, and the first mode introduces them to you in a really good fashion.

Add to the fact the game has a great audiovisual design. Backgrounds switch color well, and it just looks good on the eyes. Soundtrack is also quality stuff, alternating with the mood of the game.

I've really just played for 15 mins or so yet, but consider that within this short period of time I can say with confidence Pivvot is a great game. Especially for twitch gamers and those who love hardcore stuff in general. Reminds me a bit of Super Hexagon here, but with infinitely tighter controls and a more pleasing visual aesthetic.

reviewText:
Pivvoting is to move in a controlled point. So theres two parts imagine a stick, one side is nailed into the ground unable to move, the other side is able to move freely but only is a controlled manner to the nailed in part. So imagine a circle
______
/           \n|            |                     <---- Nailed end of the stick
\______ /
|    |
|    |
|    |
|    |
|    |
|    |
|    |
|    |
|    |
|    |
|    |
|    |
|    |
|__| <--- Free end of the stick
So the free end of the stick will only be able to move left or right on a fixed angle so lets say its 180 degrees, So the stick will only be able to move like this...
______
/           \___________________________________
|            |___________________________________|
\______/
So it would only be allowed to move this way or the other way. it would not be able to move up and down as in it goes from 180 degress to 0 or 90 degrees.

reviewText: In this game you will click one of two buttons: the button you assign to left, and the button you assign to right.  You will turn left and right to avoid running into things.  Things appear in time to the music.  If pressing left and right in time to music (which is quite decent, it's worth noting) is up your alley, then this game is worth paying a small number of USD for.  I guess I fall into that camp.

reviewText: Neat little distraction.\n\nI would recommed it if it were only Voyage and Expert Voyage modes, but strangely, the additional modes detract from the experience. In the random modes, there are too many instances where it's not possible for you to either move with the minor adjustment necessary, and if you lower the sensitivity, you aren't fast enough. It feels like the game decides whether you make it or don't, and that really sucks the fun out of it. Sadly, also takes away the feeling of accomplishment that the other modes have instilled, because you then realize it wasn't your reaction time that achived victory: it was designed to flow properly.

reviewText:
Thrilling little game.

The only controls are left and right, you control a ball attached to another ball and you have to miss obstacles as they come at you in all different shapes and sizes.

Loads of different settings. I especially like loopy mode where you have to do as many 360 degrees loops as you can.

You will die loads and loads and loads but because there is an immediate restart it's much less irritating like it should be and is in many other games!

reviewText: Felt like bit trip runner, but without the inherent feeling of fairness of that title.   Leading with the ball leaves insufficient time to react.  Trailing with the ball is dissatisfying.  Controls felt very digital, even on the x360 controller's analogue pad.  Most of my deaths came from overshooting the target via the touchy controls.    It would be nice to see analogue mouse movement as an imput mechanism.  Didn't care for it, despite playing many twitch titles over the years.\n\nAlso, the lead paragraph for the game is misleading.  Strategy is thinking long-term, there is none of that in this title.  I think they meant to say tactics...

Pivvot is certainly an interesting game with simplistic controls that make an addicting experience. With this game possessing obstacles and game modes that demand twitchy reflexes, you can inevitably be so close to your goal, when suddenly you hit the wrong direction and ruin your great run. However, when you do reach your goal, your heart might just be racing in your chest from a surge of adrenaline and maybe nerves.

While Pivvot might give these feelings to players, some might find that there is little to be had once you unlock and play all of the modes at least once. There are 8 modes, with the 2 voyage modes (Normal and Expert) suggested to be the main modes, displaying a sort of progession in difficulty as more obstacles are introduced in waves. It is a good progression, as you must successfully dodge each obstacle a set number of times before you continue, and are then incorporated into the regular waves.

Outside of these two modes, there are endless modes for both voyages, just to see how long you can last, displaying the obstacles in order of how they appear, and also Random Endless modes, throwing obstacles at you as the game pleases. The further you get in these modes, the faster the speed gets as well, increasing difficulty as well. These modes do not really add all that much to the variety of the game, because once you understand the patterns for avoiding said obstacles, it simply becomes an endurance test.

Pivvot also contains 2 other modes, Berserk and Looper. Berserk is a crazy avoidance mode that is very fast at the start, and presents scattered obstacles around that require your best abilities to get through. I find that this mode may not be for everyone who gets this game, because players might not be able to get very far, possibly only a couple of seconds, causing frustration. Looper, on the other hand, is a rather fresh mode compared to the others, looking for how many rotations you can do before you get hit. All of the other modes focus on getting through obstacles to continue on the track, but Looper changes focus by having obstacles float by you, with nothing in your path on the actual track. The better you do at Looper, the higher the difficulty becomes, and the obstacles and points you get.

Overall, this game is certainly enjoyable, but I give a very tentative recommendation. The music that this game has is rather cool and enjoyable, and allows for tension to ease a little bit, but this game is not for everyone, and it may not keep a player's for more than a couple minutes at a time, and should be played in short bursts due to the potential of feeling stressed because of the twitchy gameplay. I'm not sure if it is even worth the $5 price tag, as half of the modes are lackluster variations of the 2 voyage modes. If you seriously consider giving this shot, it would be good to wait for a sale, or possibly get lucky with acquiring a coupon.

Pivvot is certainly an interesting game with simplistic controls that make an addicting experience. With this game possessing obstacles and game modes that demand twitchy reflexes, you can inevitably be so close to your goal, when suddenly you hit the wrong direction and ruin your great run. However, when you do reach your goal, your heart might just be racing in your chest from a surge of adrenaline and maybe nerves.

Having written a guide and more recently perfected the game, it's only fitting that I write a review as well.

So, Pivvot is a ridiculously difficult rotation based game that focuses on improvement in 4 main gamemodes - Voyage, Expert Voyage, Looper, and Berserk - rather than a larger spectrum of areas. Voyage is where you're supposed to start (It's possible to start on Looper, however), and go from there. The first time I played, I had no idea what I was doing until I had died 3 times on the first obstacle, so there could use to be an in-game guide, though steam guides can typically cover a fair bit of what is needed.

So, without further ado, I guess I'll list the Pros and Cons of the game, along with a verdict...
PROS:
- Simple, yet (kinda) unique gameplay.
- Easy to grasp, difficult to master.
- More dependant on thinking how to get around an obstacle than fast reactions.
- Decent Replayability
- Low Price
- Decent Soundtrack (The Berserk theme is pretty epic)
- 4 Different gamemodes for people who enjoy different styles.

CONS:
- Berserk mode is just constantly moving back and forth - little strategy involved.
- No in-game tutorial available.
- Can be extremely frusturating at times (Anyone who watches youtube videos would consider this a pro, though)
- Looper mode is boring.

All in all, I've enjoyed the time that I have played this game, and will probably continue to play it from time to time. But now that I have all of the achievements, and have had the game proclaim me as a Pivvot God" (Yes
hoursPlayed: I will definitely not be playing it daily like I used to."

A fun and challenging fast paced indie game. Basically your ball runs along a rail and you either use left or right clicks to rotate your ball in order to dodge incoming obstacles. You only get a small window of opportunity to look at the obstacle ahead and decide which way you need to rotate which is very fun and keeps you on the edge of your seat, not to mention as you get further into a level the obstacles always change so you can never get used to dodging just one type of obstacle. The game has a decent amount of levels and an absolutely amazing soundtrack. If you're into games like oO, super hexagon and the impossible game then you're going to love this. Great game to pick up and add to your indie collection.

Wow! This game is awesome :D

Pivvot is an addicting score-attack game with an excellent soundtrack. There's not much content to speak of, but there is a decent variety of game modes to check out. Every mode is centered around dodging obstacles and staying alive for as long as you can, but each of them have slightly different objectives.

The Voyage mode(s) focus on reaching the end of a series of increasingly difficult obstacles. There's checkpoints along the way, but you're encouraged to reach the end without dying once, which will net you 2 of the game's 8 achievements (if you can manage the daunting Expert Voyage without dying of frustration). The Endless modes task you with staying alive for as long as possible while random combinations of hurdles are thrown at you at breakneck speeds.

There's one other game mode here that wasn't included in the iOS version of this game, which is called 'Looper', which is all about making complete loops while dodging projectiles that spawn in at frighteningly high intervals. It's undeniably the most difficult mode in the game, but still very addicting nonetheless.

If you enjoyed Super Hexagon ( or arcade score-attack games in general), Pivvot is an essential purchase. It's incredibly compelling, and very hard to put down once you start playing. There's also local co-op, which is nice.
Addictive cool stuff !\n\n9/10
